questions.question: What percentage of total water on earth is potable (fit for drinking)?
questions.explanation: Only about 2.7% of total water on the earth is potable. Most of the water on our planet is salty.

questions.question: Nature has fostered all forms of life on earth from:
questions.explanation: Nature has fostered all forms of life on the earth from the very beginning.

questions.question: What is the main cause of imbalance in the environment today?
questions.explanation: The main cause of imbalance in the environment is overpopulation.

questions.question: How has overpopulation affected natural resources?
options: c) Led to their blind utilization
questions.correct_answer: c) Led to their blind utilization
questions.explanation: Due to increased demand from overpopulation, natural resources have been utilized blindly.

questions.question: Water is necessary for:
options: c) Drinking, cooking, washing, cleaning, agriculture and industries
questions.correct_answer: c) Drinking, cooking, washing, cleaning, agriculture and industries
questions.explanation: Water is necessary for life. It is used for drinking, cooking, washing, cleaning, etc. Water is also required for agriculture and industries.

questions.question: How has agriculture become less weather dependent today?
options: b) Due to canals for irrigation
questions.correct_answer: b) Due to canals for irrigation
questions.explanation: Agriculture is not totally weather dependent today. Canals have been dug to provide water for irrigation.

questions.question: Seas and rivers are used for transportation by means of:
questions.explanation: Seas and rivers are used for transportation by means of ships and boats.

questions.question: Underground water is pumped out by:
options: b) Tubewells, wells and submersible pumps
questions.correct_answer: b) Tubewells, wells and submersible pumps
questions.explanation: Underground water is pumped out by tubewells, wells and submersible pumps for domestic, industrial and agricultural use.

questions.question: Dams have been made on rivers to:
options: b) Store water and generate electricity
questions.correct_answer: b) Store water and generate electricity
questions.explanation: Dams have been made on rivers to store water and to generate electricity.

questions.question: What has man used waterbodies as despite the importance of water?
questions.explanation: In spite of the obvious importance of water, man has used waterbodies as garbage dumps.

questions.question: Solid wastes and chemicals released into waterbodies threaten:
questions.explanation: Solid wastes, chemicals, etc. are released into waterbodies without much concern. All these wastes pollute water and threaten aquatic life.

questions.question: When industries use water for cooling and discharge heated water into rivers, it causes:
questions.explanation: Many industries use water for cooling purposes. This heated water is discharged in ponds, rivers, etc. causing thermal pollution.

questions.question: What does rise in temperature of waterbodies do to fish and plants?
questions.explanation: The corresponding rise in temperature in waterbodies kills many fish and plants.

questions.question: Rise in temperature of water also reduces the level of:
questions.explanation: Rise in temperature also reduces oxygen level in water.

questions.question: Oil and grease leaking from tanks and marine oil tankers form a coat on:
questions.explanation: Oil and grease leaking from tanks, specially marine oil tankers, form a coat on water surface.

questions.question: How does oil on water surface affect aquatic animals?
questions.explanation: Oil on water surface clogs gills, etc. of aquatic animals. This causes large scale death of organisms.

questions.question: On which date did the oil tanker Exxon Valdez leave its harbour?
questions.explanation: On March 23, 1989 the oil tanker Exxon Valdez left its harbour on the coast of Alaska.

questions.question: The Exxon Valdez was carrying how many million gallons of crude oil?
questions.explanation: The Exxon Valdez left with 53 million gallons of crude oil bound for California.

questions.question: Where was the Exxon Valdez headed with its cargo?
questions.explanation: The oil tanker Exxon Valdez was carrying 53 million gallons of crude oil bound for California.

questions.question: The Exxon Valdez struck which reef?
questions.explanation: Just after midnight, in the early hours of March 24, 1989, it struck the Bligh Reef, a reef off the coast of Bligh Island in Prince William Sound, Alaska.

questions.question: Where is Prince William Sound located?
questions.explanation: Prince William Sound is located in Alaska, where the Exxon Valdez oil spill occurred.

questions.question: How many million gallons of oil leaked into Prince William Sound?
questions.explanation: The collision resulted in a leakage of 11 million gallons of oil into Prince William Sound.

questions.question: How many sea birds were killed in the Exxon Valdez oil spill?
questions.explanation: Thousands of animals died immediately; Between 3 to 5 lakh sea birds were killed.

questions.question: What happened to billions of salmon and herring eggs in the oil spill?
questions.explanation: Billions of salmon and herring eggs were destroyed in the Exxon Valdez oil spill.

questions.question: How long could some shoreline habitats like contaminated mussel beds take to recover from the oil spill?
questions.explanation: Researchers estimate that some shoreline habitats, such as contaminated mussel beds, could take up to 30 years to recover.

questions.question: Which ocean animals showed stunted growth after the oil spill?
questions.explanation: In the long term, reductions in population have been seen in various ocean animals, including stunted growth in pink salmon populations.

questions.question: Sea otters and ducks showed higher death rates because they:
questions.explanation: Sea otters and ducks also showed higher death rates in the following years, partly because they ingested contaminated creatures.

questions.question: Animals were also exposed to oil when they:
options: b) Dug up their prey in contaminated soil
questions.correct_answer: b) Dug up their prey in contaminated soil
questions.explanation: Many animals were also exposed to oil when they dug up their prey in contaminated soil.

questions.question: Soil is a very important:
questions.explanation: Soil is a very important natural resource. Much of our land is covered with soil in which plants grow.

questions.question: We depend on agriculture for our:
questions.explanation: We depend on agriculture for our food. Agriculture is possible because of the presence of soil.

questions.question: Soil is being polluted with industrial and agricultural activities as well as by:
questions.explanation: Soil is being polluted with industrial and agricultural activities as well as by domestic wastes.

questions.question: What has forced farmers to use chemical fertilizers?
questions.explanation: Need for increased yield has forced farmers to use chemical fertilizers which ultimately ruin soil fertility.

questions.question: Chemical pesticides, insecticides, and weedicides pollute the soil and kill:
questions.explanation: Chemical pesticides, insecticides, weedicides, etc. pollute the soil and kill beneficial insects and worms also.

questions.question: Chemical fertilizers and pesticides should be replaced by:
questions.explanation: Chemical fertilizers and pesticides should be replaced by organic ones which do not harm the soil.

questions.question: The toxic chemicals present in industrial and domestic wastes:
questions.explanation: Industrial and domestic wastes are dumped in the soil. The toxic chemicals present in these wastes pollute soil.

questions.question: What should be done to industrial and domestic wastes before dumping in soil?
options: b) Treated to remove toxic components
questions.correct_answer: b) Treated to remove toxic components
questions.explanation: It is necessary that all industrial and domestic wastes should be treated to get rid of their toxic components before they are dumped in soil.

questions.question: Air is polluted heavily due to:
questions.explanation: Air is another important natural resource. Life is not possible without air. But air is polluted heavily due to human activities.

questions.question: Vehicles mostly run on:
questions.explanation: Vehicles are used for transport. Vehicles mostly run on petrol and diesel.

questions.question: Auto exhausts contain harmful emissions like:
options: b) Carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, nitrogen oxide and hydrocarbons
questions.correct_answer: b) Carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, nitrogen oxide and hydrocarbons
questions.explanation: Auto exhausts contain many harmful emissions like carbon monoxide, carbon dioxide, nitrogen oxide and hydrocarbons.

questions.question: Coal is burnt to produce heat in:
questions.explanation: Coal is burnt to produce heat in thermal power plants. Industries use fossil fuels like coal, petrol and diesel to produce energy.

questions.question: Industries use fossil fuels to:
options: b) Produce energy to run their machines
questions.correct_answer: b) Produce energy to run their machines
questions.explanation: Industries use fossil fuels like coal, petrol and diesel to produce energy to run their machines.

questions.question: Industrial activities release harmful gases like:
options: b) Carbon monoxide, oxides of sulphur and nitrogen
questions.correct_answer: b) Carbon monoxide, oxides of sulphur and nitrogen
questions.explanation: All these industrial activities release very harmful gases in the atmosphere. Gases like carbon monoxide, oxides of sulphur and nitrogen.

questions.question: Gases like carbon monoxide, sulphur dioxide and nitrogen can cause:
options: b) Eye and skin diseases as well as lung cancer
questions.correct_answer: b) Eye and skin diseases as well as lung cancer
questions.explanation: Gases like carbon monoxide, oxides of sulphur and nitrogen cause various eye and skin diseases as well as lung cancer.

questions.question: Sulphur dioxide and nitrogen oxide combine with water vapour to cause:
questions.explanation: Sulphur dioxide, nitrogen oxide, etc. combine with water vapour causing acid rain that harms life and property.

questions.question: Which famous monument in India is threatened by acid rain?
questions.explanation: The Taj Mahal at Agra is threatened by acid rain.

questions.question: Air pollutants like oxides of sulphur and nitrogen combine with water vapour to form:
options: b) Nitrous, nitric and sulphuric acids
questions.correct_answer: b) Nitrous, nitric and sulphuric acids
questions.explanation: Air pollutants like oxides of sulphur and nitrogen combine with water vapour in air forming nitrous, nitric and sulphuric acids.

questions.question: Sulphur dioxide causes erosion of building materials such as:
questions.explanation: Sulphur dioxide causes erosion of building materials such as limestone and marble and deterioration of statues.

questions.question: Nitrous and nitric acids have corrosive actions on:
questions.explanation: Nitrous and nitric acids also have corrosive actions on buildings, monuments, bridges, railings, etc.

questions.question: Emissions from which refinery greatly affected the Taj Mahal?
questions.explanation: Exhaust gases from Mathura Refinery greatly affected the Taj Mahal at Agra.

questions.question: What do CFC stand for?
questions.explanation: CFCs stand for Chlorofluorocarbons.

questions.question: Which appliances release CFCs in air?
options: b) Refrigerators, air conditioners, aerosol sprays like deodorants and perfumes
questions.correct_answer: b) Refrigerators, air conditioners, aerosol sprays like deodorants and perfumes
questions.explanation: Refrigerators, air conditioners, aerosol sprays like deodorants, perfumes, etc. release chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) in air.

questions.question: CFCs deplete which layer in the atmosphere?
questions.explanation: CFCs deplete the ozone layer which blocks the dangerous ultraviolet rays of the Sun.

questions.question: The ozone layer blocks which dangerous rays from the Sun?
questions.explanation: The ozone layer blocks the dangerous ultraviolet rays of the Sun.

questions.question: UV rays from the Sun can cause:
options: b) Skin cancer and other skin diseases
questions.correct_answer: b) Skin cancer and other skin diseases
questions.explanation: Ultraviolet rays can cause skin cancer and other skin diseases.

questions.question: Forests are a treasure house of:
options: b) A variety of plants and animals
questions.correct_answer: b) A variety of plants and animals
questions.explanation: Forests are a treasure house of a variety of plants and animals.

questions.question: Plants and animals in forests are essential for:
questions.explanation: These plants and animals are not only beneficial for us but are also essential for environmental balance.

questions.question: Forests have been cut down to get more land for:
questions.explanation: Forests have been cut down to get more land for housing, industries and agriculture.

questions.question: Forests have also been felled for timber for:
questions.explanation: Forests have also been felled for timber for furniture, houses, paper pulp, etc.

questions.question: Widespread deforestation has endangered:
options: b) Many rare animals and plants
questions.correct_answer: b) Many rare animals and plants
questions.explanation: Widespread deforestation has endangered many rare animals and plants.

questions.question: Deforestation has caused extensive:
questions.explanation: Deforestation has also caused extensive soil erosion and has resulted in erratic rainfall pattern in many regions of the world.

questions.question: What has resulted in erratic rainfall patterns in many regions?
questions.explanation: Deforestation has resulted in erratic rainfall pattern in many regions of the world.

questions.question: According to the chapter, man has overused natural resources:
questions.explanation: Man has overused natural resources carelessly.

questions.question: Widespread use of chemical fertilizers has led to:
questions.explanation: Widespread use of chemical fertilizers has led to infertility of soil.

questions.question: Which of the following are polluted today by human activities?
questions.explanation: Soil, water and air are polluted today by human activities.

questions.question: Acid rain harms:
questions.explanation: Acid rain harms organisms and man-made structures.

questions.question: Deforestation has threatened:
questions.explanation: Deforestation has threatened wildlife and environment.

questions.question: What was the state of human population about one century ago?
questions.explanation: About one century ago the human population was easily sustainable by nature.

questions.question: The current increase in population has led to overexploitation of:
questions.explanation: The current increase in population has disturbed all this. This overexploitation of the environment threatens all life forms today.

questions.question: What percentage of earth's water is salty (not fit for drinking)?
questions.explanation: Most of the water on our planet is salty (97.3%). Only about 2.7% of total water on the earth is potable.

questions.question: Visual evidence of the Exxon Valdez oil spill remained in areas frequented by humans for:
questions.explanation: Very little visual evidence of the event remained in areas frequented by humans just one year later.

questions.question: Do the effects of the Exxon Valdez spill continue to be felt today?
options: b) Yes, the effects continue to be felt
questions.correct_answer: b) Yes, the effects continue to be felt
questions.explanation: Very little visual evidence remained just one year later, but the effects of the spill continue to be felt today.

questions.question: Chemicals used in agriculture also pollute:
questions.explanation: Chemical pesticides, insecticides, weedicides, etc. pollute the soil and kill beneficial insects and worms also. These chemicals even pollute waterbodies.

questions.question: What type of pollution do petroleum refineries cause?
options: b) Air pollution affecting nearby buildings and monuments
questions.correct_answer: b) Air pollution affecting nearby buildings and monuments
questions.explanation: Emissions from petroleum refineries, smelters, etc. may deteriorate nearby buildings and monuments.

questions.question: Industries produce many synthetic products by processing:
questions.explanation: Industries produce many synthetic products or process natural/synthetic ores.

questions.question: All habitat and food needs for plants and animals are met by:
questions.explanation: All needs of habitat and food for both plants and animals are met by nature.

questions.question: Even human beings look to nature for:
questions.explanation: Even human beings look to nature for all their needs.

questions.question: Water is present on the earth in:
questions.explanation: Water is present on the earth in abundance. But most of the water on our planet is salty.

questions.question: Thermal pollution in waterbodies is caused by discharge of:
questions.explanation: Many industries use water for cooling purposes. This heated water is discharged in ponds, rivers, etc. causing thermal pollution.

questions.question: The Exxon Valdez oil spill occurred in which body of water?
questions.explanation: The collision resulted in a leakage of 11 million gallons of oil into Prince William Sound.

questions.question: Both long and short-term effects of the Exxon Valdez oil spill have been:
questions.explanation: Both the long and short-term effects of the oil spill have been studied comprehensively.
